div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin June 15’15
div1.p:
My dear little girl you actually did contemplate coming up or out here to help. I wrote you as I did merely to find out if you would be willing. Do you think I’d let you even if the French would? Of course not. Why if they allowed women here to nurse I never would have told you about it. At the start there were three hospitals but now they have been closed. ^No.1 was closed the night they were shelled. (They served only as a secondary poste de secours) There is a small place left where we take only terrible cases and then only at night and I understand the men there have been cite for the risk they run. I am awfully glad you were willing too [sic] serve, tho [sic] I felt all along you would. I had to laugh where you said it would be different if your father and mother could live near you for that is about as hard to accomplish as the march to Berlin. Why ^even the owner of the charming house where the chief and I have moved to isn’t allowed to come back for some important papers he left behind when he ran away. Tant mieux for Salisbury and I have a most gorgeous suite, with a marvellous [sic] bath room, and a great estate on which our windows look out. The garden is
ravishing. It is an exquisite ensemble of flowering shrubs and trees, little lily covered, iris bordered lakes, and here and there are rough stone foundations whose tinkling waters tumble in glittering cascades between riots of vividly colored flowers and dense walls of variegated verdure. When Salisbury and I are lounging in our sumptuously furnished Louis Quinze rooms I am reminded strongly of the pictures one sees of generals in 1870 besporting themselves in the splendor of a commandeered chateau. In addition we have an excellent trench exposure and can watch rifle firing at night.

Do tell me how one gets to your new apartment with the Etoile as a starting point. You know I may be able to get a leave when Paul is married to attend the function and even if I’m there but for thirty six hours I want to see you. Want to see you! If you knew how very much I really do want to be with you again.

The Boche tried to get us the other day but only managed to carry away the upper right hand corner of the caserne and block the street. As a result, however, we
have had to park our cars in widely separated places. Its an order of the Medecine Devisionaire (Thought that on the sbatuer [sp?] you told me Medecine didn’t mean doctor) who fears lest an obus will clean up our stock of cars at one fell swoop. We’ve quite an imposing section now with twenty field ambulances and a large Hotchkiss. We are also to have the Pierce - Arrow in a few days as it proved impractical on the bad roads around Dunkirk. You remember that sporty looking ambulance that was around Paris for awhile don’t you? It will look sort of out of place out here for awhile anyway.
I’ve made up my mind that the average French officer is the finest sort of fellow in the world and I’m enchanted when with them.

By the way did I write you about the sensations I had when I was twenty five yards from a marmite ^when it hit and was fortunate enough to go thru [sic] the mess that followed without being hurt. I’ve forgotten if I wrote you about it. I do not care to have any others explode that close. Two were killed twenty yards from me. One instantly, the other died
shortly afterwards.

We’re having glorious weather here now and my gardens never were prettier. Seems such a pity to let them go to waste. The only trouble is the amount of flies. They are everywhere, and as I write I have to keep slapping them away. I suppose its because of the unsanitary conditions a few hundred yards from us.
I want you to know how dearly I appreciate and how deeply grateful I am to you for writing. It is awfully nice of you and I hope you’ll keep it up.
Please give my best regards to your mother and father.
